awd_titl_txt: Virtual Organization for Computing Research in Pandemic Preparedness and Resilience
awd_abstract_narration:
This Virtual Organization (VO) will facilitate communication and collaboration among CISE scientists currently involved in pandemic research through the NSF RAPID program. With the guidance of a Steering Committee composed of members from industry, academia, and government agencies, the VO will encourage the sharing of research results in a way not available without a concerted effort. The depth and breadth of multi-disciplinary collaboration enabled by this VO will be extended to include researchers, educators, and students interested in general topics related to pandemic planning and resilience. Utilizing a variety of dissemination platforms, the VO will harness the synergies of the CISE RAPID research programs to facilitate scientific advances and advance public health in the US and around the world.

The VO will: (i) facilitate the collection of a comprehensive collection of data sets, software tools, and documentation that can be shared by the research community; (ii) identification of new research efforts resulting from the cross fertilization of ideas from various subdisciplines of CISE research; (iii) a research roadmap that proposes research directions in CISE sciences that can lead to effective methods to prepare for and recover from future pandemics; and (iv) training and other pedagogic materials needed for educating future generations of scientists in topics related to pandemic preparedness, recovery, and resilience. The increased levels of collaboration fostered by this VO have the potential to result in innovative computational methods and technologies for dealing with future pandemics. The research roadmap will include identification of key research topics, risks, and gaps in the current R&D landscape that will significantly benefit the research community and serve as the blueprint for researchers, funding agencies, and policy makers on the role of information and communication technologies (ICT) in developing break-through solutions for pandemic resilience. While it is not possible to prevent pandemics completely, developing resilience techniques will enable society to prepare for and cope with the aftermath in a more effective manner.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

NSF PREPARE: Building a Resilient Future Through Pandemic Research

The NSF PREPARE (Pandemic Research for Resilience and Preparedness) project is a virtual organization dedicated to fostering a global community of researchers focused on pandemic preparedness. By promoting interdisciplinary collaboration and leveraging advanced computational tools, PREPARE aims to develop innovative solutions to enhance our ability to respond to and recover from pandemics.

Community Building: One of the primary achievements of NSF PREPARE is the creation of a robust, interdisciplinary community. The project has engaged scientists from various fields, including sociology, criminal justice, public health, and computational epidemiology. Domestic and global partnerships have been instrumental in broadening the scope of pandemic research and fostering international cooperation.

Workshops and Events: PREPARE has hosted numerous virtual workshops and events, attracting over 2000 participants. These workshops have covered a wide range of topics, from data access and computational resources to social, behavioral, economic, and governance issues during pandemics. The project has also organized specialized workshops on scalable computing and vaccine-preventable diseases, providing a platform for researchers to share their findings and collaborate on new initiatives.

Research and Publications: PREPARE has been active in promoting pandemic preparedness through various channels, including podcasts, YouTube, and its website. The "Science before the Storm" podcast has featured interviews with experts from diverse disciplines, fostering cross-disciplinary dialogue and collaboration. The project has also published research findings in reputable journals, such as the SPRINT team's paper in the journal Scientific Data.

Data Collection and Analysis: One component of PREPARE's work has been the collection and analysis of non-pharmaceutical intervention (NPI) data. Undergraduate students from the University of Virginia (UVA) have gathered county-level data on interventions like mask mandates, business closures, and school closures. This data is crucial for evaluating the effectiveness of various measures and informing future pandemic responses.

Digital Twins of Epidemic outbreaks: PREPARE has contributed to the development of synthetic datasets (digital twins) that simulate realistic disease outbreaks, based on feedback from the community as part of the roadmap development. This is useful for development of new epidemiological and machine learning tools. This will also allow researchers to develop and test privacy-preserving methods for predicting infection risks. One such dataset was used to support development of new privacy-enhancing technologies, as part of  the US-UK Prize Challenge. This initiative highlights the importance of balancing data privacy with the need for accurate and timely public health information.

Impact and Future Directions: The impact of NSF PREPARE extends beyond immediate research outcomes. By building a global network of researchers and promoting interdisciplinary collaboration, the project is laying the groundwork for a more resilient and prepared society. The Research Roadmap developed by PREPARE outlines key research topics, risks, and gaps in the current landscape, serving as a blueprint for future efforts in pandemic resilience.

In summary, NSF PREPARE is making significant contributions to pandemic preparedness by fostering a collaborative research community, advancing educational initiatives, and developing innovative solutions to public health challenges. Through its ongoing efforts, PREPARE is helping to ensure that we are better equipped to face future pandemics with resilience and preparedness.
